description: Lenart Kova decides against leaking the full BCI secrets. Instead, he collaborates discreetly with key Council technocrats, proposing a controlled rollout of 'Redemption Games'—community-based challenges designed to restore BCI services without full disclosure of system abuses.

The Council, guided by Lenart’s technical input, launches the BCI’s 'Redemption Games' across districts. Each area receives a tailored set of moral and cooperative challenges—helping the vulnerable, collective decision-making, or negotiating resource use—to regain access to basic services.

Neighborhood groups rapidly mobilize to tackle the challenges. Some communities strengthen internal bonds through cooperation, while others fracture amid disagreements over ethical tactics or sacrifice. Tensions simmer as the ethics and legitimacy of the games are hotly debated.

As certain districts succeed and see partial BCI service restored, rivalry intensifies between neighborhoods. Accusations of sabotage and unfair play emerge, fueling distrust between communities even as internal solidarity grows.

Council-controlled media celebrate the 'games' as a system repair success, but public discussions shift toward questioning central authority. Local leaders debate whether increased neighborhood autonomy signals the end of BCI dominance or a temporary phase in Stenograd’s crisis.
